rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the constitution of hevea resin and serum.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: At the present time the tree Hevea Brasiliensis is the only important source of rubber. The raw rubber formed by the coagulation of Hevea latex consists mainly of the hydrocarbon caoutchouc; and with the caoutchouc is associated protein and a somewhat variable amount of acetone soluble substances called collectively the resin. It may be stated on general grounds that a full knowledge of the chemical nature of rubber is essential to its most efficient utilization. There are considerable differences in the vulcanization properties of rubber prepared by different methods and there are, as with all natural products, variations in quality of similarily prepared specimens from season to season and from tree to tree.[...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Preparation of compounds contributory to the study of the mechanism of vulcanization catalysis ; Acid numbers in raw rubber samples.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Goodyear was the first to employ a catalyst in heating rubber and sulphur together, thus originating the process known as vulcanisation. This catalyst was an inorganic lead compound; and inorganic catalysts, especially compounds of lead, magnesium and calcium, have been in general use in the rubber industry since Goodyear's discovery. Vulcanisation has such an important effect on the physical properties of rubber that the process now occupies a very prominent part in the manufacture of rubber goods. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.
Rubber.
Vulcanization.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The description, habits and life history of the onion maggot Hylemyia antiqua Meig, with special reference to its control in the district of Montreal, Quebec.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The onion maggot, Hylemyia antique Meig., has been regarded as a pest in Canada since 1885 when Dr. James Fletcher in his annual report mentioned one case of a loss of 75% due to this insect. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Onion maggot.
Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Studies concerning the mosaic disease of tobacco.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: In view of the difficulty experienced by experimenters in attributing the various mosaic or "virus" diseases to any specific organism, and in view of the fact that several workers have recently shown the presence of intracellular bodies in cells of plants affected with certain of these diseases, it seemed an opportune moment to undertake the present study, which has to do mainly with the eytological aspects of the Mosaic Disease of Tobacco, and, in particular, with the intracellular bodies found in connection therewith. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Tobacco mosaic virus.
Plant Anatomy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A comparative study of the male genitalia of the Canadian Pentatomidae.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This paper is intended primarily as a contribution to the morphology of the male genital structures of the Pentatomidae. Incidentally it may offer some suggestions as to the relationships of the families of the order. Study was made of a wide range of literature dealing with the genitalia of other groups that appeared to have any features in common with the genitalia of the Pentatomidae. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hemiptera.
Entomology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some thermal constants of carbon dioxide.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: For many years, low temperature research has held a certain fascination for many workers. The results of investigation, however, have not been very plentiful, especially in the realm of latent heats of fusion. In reality there are very few substances whose latent heats of fusion and specific heats at low temperatures are accurately known. Regardless of this fact, many investigators have promulgated theories based on low temperature data that are hardly permissible because of the small number of experimental results available. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The virgin birth of Christ.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: At a comparatively early date in the history of the Christian church it was made a part of the creed, to which every believer was required to subscribe, that Jesus Christ was bornof the Virgin Mary. The reason for this was of course the fact that the doctrine had scriptural authority. Of the four gospels which were accepted by the church as true accounts of the events recorded therein, the two which gave any account of the birth of Jesus at all represented Him as being born of a virgin. There was no difficulty whatever at that time in accepting such a story as literally true. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Classics.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Sizing on sieves : a critical study of the inter-relation of the different factors in sieving.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Sizing by means of sieves, or screening, is today one of the most important operations in ore dressing and many other of the mineral industries. It finds use in practically every ore dressing plant in connection with closed circuit grinding, the separation into classes on a basis of coarseness of the different grains preceding some form of concentration or in the preparation of a final product. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ore Dressing.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Heating and ventilation of electrical machinery.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The losses in electrical machinery are converted into heat causing a rise of temperature at the source of loss. From this point the heat is transmitted to the surrounding air by conduction, convection and radiation. In order that a flow of heat may take place there must be a temperature difference and the heat flows in the direction of diminishing temperature, so that the mighest temperature, or what has been called the hot spot, of an electrical machine is at the source of loss while the temperature is a minimum at thepoints where the heat leaves the machine. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Electrical Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The chemical constitution of the human placenta.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the last fifteen years considerable study has been made of most of the organs of the human body and among these is the placenta. Medical schools have attempted to learn its physiological functions, especially as to the part it plays in the production of certain pathological conditions. Bio-chemists have investigated its chemical nature. Others have studied it from yet different points of view. This paper has for its object to review the work on the chemical constitution of the placenta and with the presentation of some results of our own. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Chemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The taxation of corporations in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Canada was taken from the French by the British in 1763, the financial problem was settled by the Quebec Revenue Act of 1774. By this act a scale of customs duties was established by the Imperial authorities, and the French territorial and casual revenues existing at the conquest were retained and collected by British officials. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics & Political Science.
Corporations -- Taxation -- Canada.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Concrete columns plain and reinforced.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: During the last fifteen years concrete has been gradually replacing other building materials and is now practically universally used in the construction of wharves, piers, retaining walls, dams etc., and in buildings to be used for manufacturing, warehousing and storage purposes. This has been due to its cheapness and the ease with which it can be handled. Its fireproofing quality has also been a large factor in its use in buildings. The increasing demand, and the great variety of structures in which it has come to be used,has called for a thorough knowledge of its properties in order to establish a basis for design. To obtain this, experiments have been made in Europe and America by the various governments, universities and engineering societies. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Civil Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A petrographical study of the Dyke rocks of the Anyox district, British Columbia.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The Hidden Creek Mines are situated at Anyox near the head of Observatory Inlet, one of the many long fjords which so deeply penetrate the Coast of British Columbia and affording comparatively easy and direct routes to the interior of the country which, through its mountainous and wooded character, would otherwise be of extremely difficult access. In this way Anyox, while enjoying the advantages of a sea port, is in reality inland, being in the heart of the Coast Range, the most western mountain system of the mainland of the Province. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Geology & Mineralogy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: A study of the fixation of phosphates by soils.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A study of the fixation of phosphates by soils requires a correct understanding of the terms absorption and adsorption. The term absorption is used in general to designate the process by which a solid or liquid draws into itself, and retains within its structure, or on its surface another liquid solid or gas. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Soils -- Phosphorus content.
Chemistry.
Phosphates.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Taxation of income in Canada.
rdf:Description.dc:contributor: Department of Economics and Political Science
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The income tax as a serious factor in the general scheme of taxation is a comparatively recent arrival. [...] As in England and in the United States, Canada's first federal income tax was the result of the necessities of war finance. The enormous increase in expenditure necessitated by the war was first met by borrowing. Other taxes, such as customs and excise duties, were increased and in 1916 recourse was had to the Business Profits War Tax. By 1917 the national debt was rising at such a rate that it became increasingly evident that some new mode of taxation must be found, and the Income Tax Act was passed in July 1917. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Economics & Political Science.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Injection of tissue extracts into the blood stream with special reference to blood coagulation.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: At least as early as 1834 it had been shown that bruised tissue has some relationship to coagulation, for Carpenter in his "Principles of Human Physiology" states that M. Dupuy found that the injection of cerebral substance into the veins of an animal occasioned its death almost as instantaneously as if prussic acid had been administered, the circulation being rapidly brought to a stand by the formation of voluminous clots in the heart and large vessels. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Canadian orators and oratory.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: That the future of Canada is assured only by her adoption of a more independent national policy, has become more and more the common opinion of those who unblinded by selfish and pessimistic sentiment, see a not far distant era, when Canada shall hold no small place among the nations of the world. Not through annexation, not through Imperialism but through Nationalism, must she pierce the clouds of hesitancy, of indecision, and of despair, in which too much dependence and lack of confidence have enveloped her. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Canada. Parliament.
English.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Some ethical aspects of modern charity problems.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: According to C. S. Lock'ss definition - "Charity or love represents the principle of the good life, it stands for a mood or habit of mind and an endeavor". A closer definition, he says, would be "Good-will in the broadest sends towards the community and its members. Thus, in the word charity religious and social associations meet, and thus regarded the word means a disciplined and habitual mood in which the mind is considerate of the welfare of others individually and generally and desires what is for their real good. By the word "charity", as the term will be used in this thesis, we mean all those institutions and agencies which exist for the purpose of giving direct material aid to the poor and the distressed as such. It will be necessary in a limited treatment of so vast a subject to leave out of the discussion various relief organizations which, technicaily speaking,come under the general category of charities. We will not consider, for instance, purely educational institutions, because the aid given is not primarily material assistance. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Philosophy.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Geology and some of the mineral resources of China.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The science of geology evolved from the study of cosmogony, while cosmogony, which in the very early days was studied as a matter of speculation in the light of philosophy, originated in mythology. According to the mythology of the ancient Egyptians, It was Muduk who, assisted by his gods and the winds, created the heavens and the earth out of the bodyof Tiamat whom he had vanquished. The old Greeks believed the Olympian gods were the makers of the universe; whereas the Hebrews maintained that it was the Personal God who createdthe universe. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: GeologicalSciences.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: Cause of death in mammals from lowered body temperature.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: The following experiments were undertaken with a view to obtaining more information as to the cause of death from lowered body temperature and to ascertain the changes that occur in the heart before its function is arrested. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Hypothermia.
Death -- Causes.
Physiology.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: An experimental study of mechanical filtration, with especial reference to the use of rotary drum filters on slimes from ore dressing plants.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: This subject is of great scientific and commercial importance due to the difficulties which arise in the practical work of separating solution from finely divided material of one kind or another, one or both of which are valuable. For example, in the sugar industry filters are used to separate the sugar solution from pieces of cane or other solids collected in the process of obtaining the sugar from its original source. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Ore Dressing.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The heats of solution of certain Alkali halides and the specific heats of their solutions.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Almost the earliest calorimetric work was that performed by Black in 1762 in his work upon the latent heat of fusion Improvements in apparatus and refinements in technique were applied to thermochemistry from time to time, the first of importance being introduced by Favre and Silvermann about 1852. The greater part of the experimental work in the early days of thermochemistry was carried out by Thomsen and Berthelot, who, with their collaborators, produced much data relating to heats of reaction. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biochemistry.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The effect of a small variation in the percentage of cement on the strength of some standard mixes of concrete.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: There seems, at the present time, to be no little confusion between engineers and contractors when they are discussing the amount of materials to be contained in a certain mix. In the past, many concrete specifications have been drawn up and have failed to state the proportions by definite weight or vol1une, but give the quantities simply in "parts." This kind of specification left much to the honesty of the contractor who could choose within certain limits, which would not be altogether too grotesque, what he would consider to be the weight of a cubic foot of cement. By this method of simply stating the quantities by parts an unscrupulous contractor can measure a oubio foot of cement very loosely packed andthus produce too lean a concrete. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Engineering.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The elimination of error in taking yields of forage crops.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: A survey of the present-day situation with regard to Field Husbandry experimentation brings out the fact that there is a growing tendency towards developing finer and more accurate methods of procedure in order that experimental error may be reduced to a minimum. Marked progress in many phases of this work can be detected. [...]
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Agronomy.
Agricultural estimating and reporting.
Forage plants.

rdf:Description.dcterms:title: The church school in the modern state: its provinceand problems.
rdf:Description.dc:abstract: Aristotle declared that man is a political animal. Plato, in the second book of his 'Republic', showed that men are not self-sufficient, but that they attain full development only in an organized comnunity, in which individual effort affects other men. In succeeding chapters he develops his theory of an ideal state, the chief safe-guard of which is to be found in education. The governors, he says, must be careful to preserve music and gymnastic from innovation, quoting Damon to the effect that a change in the songs of a country would soon result ln the alteration of its laws. [...]
rdf:Description.ual:supervisor: Dale, J. & Tait, W & Macmillan, C. (Supervisors)
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Education.
